title: Suben las bolsas de todo el mundo tras el acuerdo temporal entre Estados Unidos y China para reducir aranceles
content: Los precios del petróleo también experimentaron alzas significativas, con el crudo de referencia estadounidense WTX ganando 1,66 dólares, hasta 62,68 dólares por barril, mientras que el crudo Brent, ...
resumen:
Los mercados bursátiles mundiales y los futuros estadounidenses registraron importantes alzas este lunes después de que Estados Unidos y China anunciaran una suspensión temporal de 90 días en la mayoría de los elevados aranceles que ambas naciones habían impuesto durante los últimos meses.

En una declaración conjunta emitida tras intensas negociaciones celebradas durante el fin de semana en Ginebra, Suiza, ambas potencias acordaron reducir sustancialmente sus gravámenes para dar tiempo a más conversaciones. Estados Unidos disminuirá sus aranceles sobre productos chinos al 30% desde un máximo del 145%, mientras que China rebajará sus tarifas sobre bienes estadounidenses al 10% desde el 125%.

El secretario del Tesoro estadounidense, Scott Bessent, declaró que se han hecho "progresos sustanciales" en las conversaciones comerciales. La Casa Blanca saludó lo que calificó como un nuevo “acuerdo comercial”. El Ministerio de Comercio chino también celebró el “progreso sustancial” alcanzado.

El futuro del S&P 500 subió un 2,6% y el del Promedio Industrial Dow Jones un 2%.

Los precios del petróleo también experimentaron alzas significativas, con el crudo de referencia estadounidense WTX ganando 1,66 dólares, hasta 62,68 dólares por barril, mientras que el crudo Brent, el estándar internacional, sumó 1,63 dólares, alcanzando los 65,55 dólares por barril.

En los mercados cambiarios, el dólar estadounidense avanzó frente al yen japonés, cotizando a 148,18 yenes, frente a 146,17 yenes previos. El euro, por su parte, cayó a 1,1107 dólares, desde los 1,1209 dólares anteriores.

La bolsa de Hong Kong registró un salto del 3%, cerrando en 23.558,11 puntos. El mercado de Tokio logró una ligera subida de menos del 0,1%, situándose en 37.644,26 puntos. El Índice Compuesto de Shanghai repuntó un 0,8%, hasta los 3.369,24 puntos, el Kospi de Seúl ganó un 1,2%, alcanzando los 2.607,33 puntos, y el Taiex taiwanés avanzó un 1%. El S&P/ASX 200 australiano mostró una subida inferior al 0,1%, cerrando en 8.233,50 puntos.

El DAX alemán ganó un 1%, situándose en 23.723,55 puntos, mientras que el CAC 40 parisino sumó un 0,8%, hasta los 7.805,62 puntos. El FTSE 100 británico mostró un avance más modesto, con una subida del 0,1%, hasta los 8.560,42 puntos.

El Sensex de Bombay se disparó un 3,2%, mientras que el índice KSE 100 de Pakistán registró un salto de más del 9%.

El Fondo Monetario Internacional desembolsará aproximadamente 1.000 millones de dólares como parte de un paquete de rescate para la economía pakistaní.

Donald Trump anunció el 2 de abril la imposición de aranceles a sus socios comerciales, con los más elevados dirigidos a Beijing, hasta alcanzar un máximo del 145%, lo que provocó tarifas de represalia del 125% por parte del gigante asiático.

Las conversaciones del fin de semana entre el secretario del Tesoro estadounidense, Scott Bessent, y el representante comercial, Jamieson Greer, con el viceprimer ministro chino, He Lifeng, y el representante de comercio internacional, Li Chenggang, han supuesto las primeras negociaciones conocidas desde el anuncio del “Día de la Liberación” de Trump.

Tai Hui, estratega jefe de mercados para Asia-Pacífico de JP Morgan Asset Management, señaló que la reducción arancelaria es "muy significativa, mayor de lo esperado".

Karsten Junius, de Bank J. Safra Sarasin, advirtió que los mercados financieros podrían seguir siendo volátiles.

title: What’s next with Trump’s trade war truce with China
content: The Trump administration agreed after talks this weekend in Switzerland to pare back its 145% in tariffs charged on imports from China to 30%. The Chinese government chose to reduce its retaliatory ...
resumen: President Donald Trump’s agreement with China to temporarily slash tariffs for 90 days offered the world a bit of welcome relief. The Trump administration agreed after talks this weekend in Switzerland to pare back its 145% in tariffs charged on imports from China to 30%. The Chinese government chose to reduce its retaliatory import taxes on U.S. goods from 125% to 10% while the sides continue to negotiate. Trump declared the de-escalation of the trade war a victory. The tariffs are now elevated from when Trump took office. The U.S. president and his aides have made it clear that most imports will be taxed at a minimum of roughly 10%. The 10% figure has been Trump’s baseline. Trump’s new 30% tariff on Chinese goods includes 20% tied to China’s role in fentanyl and the 10% baseline applied elsewhere. Trump said on Friday, “We have many deals coming down the line, but we always have a baseline of 10%.” Sectoral tariffs of 25% on autos, steel and aluminum are still in place, with Trump stressing that pharmaceutical drugs will also soon face import taxes. Trump said Monday that he told House Speaker Mike Johnson and Senate Majority Leader John Thune to include tariff revenues when looking at how to pay for their planned income tax cuts. Taisu Zhang, a law professor who studies comparative legal and economic history at Yale University, said the chaos from last month probably was not for nothing. The stock market loved the news. The S&P 500 stock index jumped 3.3% in Monday trading. Michael Starr, vice president of growth at the logistics company Zencargo, said there is “absolutely” going to be a bullwhip effect. University of Michigan economist Justin Wolfers stressed that many people would see the 90-day talks as a short-term positive. Kevin Rinz, a senior fellow at the Washington Center for Equitable Growth, said 30% tariffs are still a cost for businesses and consumers to absorb. Rinz, who worked as an economist in the Obama and Biden administrations, tried to model the impact of the labor market based on Trump’s own premise that any short-term pain from tariffs would eventually result in long-term gains. His analysis found a drop in hiring.

title: Aditex expresa preocupación ante grave situación sector textil nacional
content: Aditex destaca que la industria textil local, conformada en su mayoría por micro, pequeñas y medianas empresas, atraviesa una encrucijada crítica.
resumen: La Asociación Dominicana de Industriales Textiles (Aditex) expresó preocupación ante la grave situación que enfrenta el sector textil nacional, con una pérdida reciente de unos 2,500 empleos que pone en riesgo a más de 70,000 trabajadores directos. La industria textil local, conformada en su mayoría por micro, pequeñas y medianas empresas, atraviesa una encrucijada crítica. La competencia desleal derivada de importaciones a precios de dumping, principalmente desde China, junto con el creciente comercio de ropa nueva y usada conocida como «pacas» y “tanques” ha provocado una fuerte disminución en la demanda de productos nacionales. A esto se suman barreras estructurales como el acceso limitado a financiamiento y la ausencia de programas de formación técnica especializada. Países como México y Honduras también han sufrido la pérdida de miles de empleos en sus industrias textiles. Colombia y México han adoptado medidas proteccionistas, imponiendo aranceles de hasta un 30% y 40%, respectivamente sobre productos textiles terminados importados. Leah Francis Campos, embajadora nominada por el presidente estadounidense Donald Trump, manifestó su intención de colaborar con el gobierno dominicano para contrarrestar prácticas comerciales desleales y enfrentar la creciente influencia de China en la región. Aditex hizo un llamado al Gobierno dominicano, al sector privado y a las instituciones financieras para trabajar juntos en la implementación de medidas urgentes. Entre las acciones propuestas destaca el establecimiento de políticas arancelarias que protejan la producción local, el acceso a créditos blandos para modernizar procesos productivos, y el impulso de programas de formación técnica especializada. Considera también prioritario regular la importación de ropa, fortalecer los mecanismos de defensa comercial frente al dumping y promover el consumo de productos textiles fabricados en el país. Propone revisar, mantener, fortalecer y ampliar los programas institucionales dirigidos a las mipymes, como los de confección de uniformes escolares, policiales, militares y de otras entidades del Estado.

Se está trabajando en la diversificación de exportación para aprovechar nuevas oportunidades en mercados alternativos, y se va a intensificar la búsqueda de nuevos compradores.

La puesta en funcionamiento del megapuerto de Chancay "está favoreciendo el envío de productos frescos al Asia con monitoreo de temperatura".

De ponerse en marcha estos aranceles, podría afectar en 0,5 puntos porcentuales el crecimiento del país.

title: América Latina teme la caída de las remesas
content: Más allá de la geopolítica que pretende redibujar fronteras, o cambiar de pronto tratados internacionales como el del Canal de Panamá, o subvertir alianzas tradicionales como la de Estados Unidos con ...
resumen:
Las clases populares de América Latina temen la drástica caída de las remesas de los emigrantes.

Una parte importante de la población de América Latina sobrevive gracias al envío de remesas de dinero de sus familiares en el exterior.

La inflación por los cambios económicos por aplicación de nuevos aranceles, retracción económica, o cualquier otra causa, va a limitar la capacidad de ahorro de esos inmigrantes, preferentemente los hispanos en Estados Unidos.

En sus últimas previsiones, el Fondo Monetario Internacional advertía de un posible retroceso del crecimiento de la economía mundial en medio punto, que llegaba hasta un punto de caída en Estados Unidos por el impacto de las decisiones económicas de Donald Trump.

Fue precisamente en la sede del Fondo Monetario Internacional, en Washington, donde su entonces Gerente, Rodrigo Rato, nos mostró con detalle en sus estudios el impacto de las remesas en una parte importante de los países del mundo.

Se sabe de la existencia de remesas y de una potente estructura comercial de casas de envíos de dinero; pero no se conoce cuan vital es esa aportación para la vida y la estabilidad de tantos países.

Destacó el caso de El Salvador, e incluso el de Haití.

Puso el ejemplo de localidades mexicanas de escasos recursos donde, sin embargo, sobrevivía con relativa solvencia una sucursal bancaria que gestionaba, básicamente, el único gran ingreso en la economía local: las remesas.

Un grupo de venezolanos, perfectamente legalizados, explicaban estos días como suspendieron una visita concertada al Congreso de los Estados Unidos simplemente por temor.

Las agencias turísticas españolas estiman en unos doce mil los viajeros que han desistido por el momento de esas vacaciones, en los últimos tres meses, optando por destinos menos arriesgados.

title: Niño Becerra enciende las alarmas: “En verano podemos llegar a una situación Covid de paralización de la economía mundial”
content: Esto está creando una confrontación con China y ha generado una fuerte caída de las bolsas. Sobre esto se ha pronunciado Santiago Niño Becerra, un reconocido economista español y catedrático de ...
resumen:
El economista Santiago Niño Becerra advierte sobre una posible parálisis económica en 2025.

Niño Becerra, catedrático de Estructura Económica en el Instituto Químico de Sarriá de la Universidad Ramón Llull de Barcelona desde 1994, ha mostrado un gráfico de Standard's&Poor's y ha explicado que uno de los momentos más bajos fue con la crisis del 2008, cuando la bolsa estaba a 735 de índice, mientras que el más alto ha sido en 2025, a 6.101.

El economista ha declarado: "No nos tenemos que preocupar en absoluto, a no ser que baje un 80%. Pero que baje un 10% más no tiene ningún tipo de importancia (...) Se ha multiplicado por 8,3 veces. Esto es absurdo, no tiene lógica. Solo hay una razón, y es la especulación. Con todo el dinero que los bancos centrales han inyectado gratis en la economía en los años 2009, 2012 y 2018, con la pandemia se ha inyectado en las bolsas".

Niño Becerra ha detallado que si la situación empeora con más aranceles y réplicas, en verano se podría llegar a una situación Covid: de paralización de la economía mundial.

El experto ha explicado que lo que más le preocupa es que esta situación no se resuelva.

El economista ha asegurado que en este momento cree que China va ganando en esta guerra: "Tiene más activos. Aprendió del colonialismo americano. Está quitando recursos a Sudamérica y África, pero les hace cosas. Les hace obras, les construye instalaciones. Les compensa".

title: Consumers get a 3-month reprieve as U.S. and China agree to temporarily slash tariffs
content: GENEVA — The United States and China have agreed to temporarily slash reciprocal tariffs in a deal that surpassed expectations as the world’s two biggest economies seek to end a damaging trade war ...
resumen: The United States and China have agreed to temporarily slash reciprocal tariffs. The U.S. will cut extra tariffs it imposed on Chinese imports in April this year to 30% from 145% and Chinese duties on U.S. imports will fall to 10% from 125%. The new measures are effective for 90 days. U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer attended a news conference after trade talks with China in Geneva, Switzerland, May 12, 2025. Dow futures surged Monday after the deal was announced. Wall Street cheered the development with futures for the S&P 500 jumping 3.1%, while futures for the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 2.5%. Futures for the Nasdaq, home to the biggest U.S. technology companies, soared 3.9%. American microchip companies, including ON Semiconductor, Micron and Broadcom, were among the biggest gainers early Monday. ON Semiconductor, Micron and Broadcom all soared between 6% and 8%. Nvidia rose 4.8%. Travel companies also enjoyed big gains, with American, Delta and United Airlines all up around 7%. Retailers, including Amazon (up 7.8%) and Best Buy (jumped 10.4%), also benefited from the announced tariff pause. The tariff dispute had brought nearly $600 billion in two-way trade to a standstill. The Geneva meetings were the first face-to-face interactions between senior U.S. and Chinese economic officials since Trump returned to power. Bessent said the deal did not include sector-specific tariffs. Zhiwei Zhang, chief economist at Pinpoint Asset Management in Hong Kong, said, "This is better than I expected. I thought tariffs would be cut to somewhere around 50%." Trump had hiked the tariffs paid by U.S. importers for goods from China to 145% since taking office in January. China hit back by putting export curbs on some rare earth elements and raising tariffs on U.S. goods to 125%. Shares in European firms hit by the trade war rallied after the deal. Shipping company Maersk was the biggest gainer in Europe, up more than 12%. Shares in luxury firms LVMH and Gucci-owner Kering were up 7.4% and 6.7% respectively. Wall Street stock futures climbed as the talks boosted hopes a global recession might be averted. Trump said the two sides had negotiated “a total reset... in a friendly, but constructive, manner.” Greer said conversations over curbing the deadly opioid fentanyl were “very constructive” though on a separate track. U.S. and Chinese officials met over two days at the Swiss U.N. ambassador’s gated villa overlooking Lake Geneva.

title: Estados Unidos y China reducen aranceles al 30% y 10% en tregua comercial de 90 días
content: El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos afirma que la crisis arancelaria entre su país y China es equivalente a un embargo, y que ninguno de los dos lo desea.
resumen:
China y EE. UU. han pactado una tregua de tres meses en la guerra comercial que libran desde febrero pasado.
China reducirá del 125% al 10% los aranceles sobre productos estadounidenses.
EE. UU. bajará los que aplica a los bienes chinos del 145% al 30%.
El pacto fue anunciado el lunes 12 de mayo en un comunicado conjunto difundido tras las negociaciones celebradas en Ginebra el fin de semana por representantes de sus respectivos gobiernos.
Acordaron crear un mecanismo permanente de consulta.
Este instrumento de diálogo estará liderado por el viceprimer ministro chino, He Lifeng; el secretario del Tesoro de EE. UU., Scott Bessent, así como el representante comercial de ese país, Jamieson Greer.
Podrán reunirse en China, en EE. UU. o en un tercer país.
Durante la tregua de 90 días, ambos países continuarán con negociaciones de carácter más técnico.
Bessent indicó desde Ginebra que no solo incluirán cuestiones arancelarias, sino también otras medidas que obstaculizan el comercio, en particular de parte de China.
El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, afirmó que ninguna de las partes desea un desacoplamiento (del comercio) y que lo que ha pasado con aranceles tan altos equivale a un embargo.
Jamieson Greer dijo en Ginebra que en estos dos días se abordó por primera vez de forma directa con China el problema del fentanilo, y que se pidió a ese país que tome medidas drásticas contra la producción y exportación ilegal de los químicos que permiten su elaboración.
Los mercados bursátiles han reaccionado a la tregua comercial con avances.
Las principales bolsas de Europa suben entre el 0.5% y el 1.6%.
El índice Euro Stoxx 50, que agrupa a las mayores cotizadas del Viejo Continente, avanza el 1.7%.
Hong Kong avanzó un 2.98%.
Shanghái y Shenzhen repuntaron el 0.82% y el 1.72%, respectivamente.
Tokio, el 0.38%.
El euro marcaba a la apertura de los mercados bursátiles en Europa su nivel mínimo en un mes frente al dólar, y se cambiaba a US$1.11.
El petróleo Brent sube un 3.6%, hasta US$66.25 el barril.
El oro pierde un 3% y cotiza en US$3,229 la onza.
El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, y el representante comercial de Estados Unidos, Jamieson Greer, son los responsables de las negociaciones directas con China.

title: CRT busca diversificar mercados y reducir aranceles en India, China y República Dominicana
content: El nuevo presidente del Consejo Regulador del Tequila, Aurelio López Rocha, afirmó que la política arancelaria del presidente Donald Trump no ha afectado las ventas a Estados Unidos.
resumen:
El Consejo Regulador del Tequila (CRT) busca diversificar mercados y reducir aranceles en India, China y República Dominicana.

El presidente del CRT, Aurelio López Rocha, afirmó que la política arancelaria del presidente Donald Trump no ha afectado las ventas de tequila a Estados Unidos, que representa el 84% de las exportaciones.

De enero a marzo de 2025, las exportaciones de tequila a Estados Unidos aumentaron 14.1 millones de litros en comparación con el mismo período del año anterior, pasando de 75.7 millones de litros en el primer trimestre de 2024 a 89.8 millones de litros en los primeros tres meses de 2025.

El CRT reforzará la gestión para que países como China, India y República Dominicana reduzcan sus tarifas arancelarias.

Actualmente, India tiene un arancel del 150% para el tequila, China del 10% y República Dominicana del 20%.

El director del CRT, Ramón González, mencionó que el gobierno de la India publicó un beneficio para el Whiskey, reduciendo el arancel al 75% ad valorem con la esperanza de llegar al 40%.

El CRT está impulsando ocho líneas estratégicas de acción para contribuir con la planeación estratégica de la cadena productiva Agave-Tequila.

800 productores han obtenido la certificación Agave Responsable Social (ARS), comercializando más de 15,000 toneladas de agave, lo que ha representado 80 millones de pesos de beneficio directo a los agricultores.

Ramón González hizo un llamado a la Secretaría de Economía del gobierno federal para que emita una Norma Oficial Mexicana de Emergencia para los destilados, aguardientes y licores hechos a base de agave.

title: Sheinbaum califica de «injusta» restricción de EEUU al ganado de México
content: Trump ya había advertido que impondría restricciones si México no actuaba contra el gusano barrenador antes de abril.
resumen: La presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, calificó como “injusta” la decisión del gobierno de Estados Unidos de bloquear temporalmente la entrada de ganado mexicano debido a la presencia del gusano barrenador. Ambos gobiernos anunciaron la medida el pasado domingo y establecieron una suspensión de 15 días al ingreso de ganado en pie desde México, con el objetivo de revisar las estrategias para el control de esta plaga. Durante su conferencia matutina de este lunes, Sheinbaum expresó su desacuerdo con la medida al declarar: «No estamos de acuerdo, no hay razón para cerrar la frontera». El gusano barrenador del ganado es la larva de una mosca parasitaria que invade heridas abiertas en animales de sangre caliente, alimentándose del tejido vivo y causando graves daños a la salud del ganado. Estados Unidos decidió bloquear temporalmente la entrada del ganado mexicano. En abril, el presidente estadounidense Donald Trump ya había advertido que implementaría restricciones si México no tomaba medidas claras antes de finalizar el mes. Sheinbaum defendió la actuación de su gobierno y aseguró que han implementado acciones para contener la plaga, la cual, según explicó, «normalmente viene por la frontera sur» del país. Cifras oficiales indican que México exportó en 2024 poco más de un millón de cabezas de ganado a Estados Unidos. Pese a la suspensión, la mandataria descartó consecuencias económicas graves y confió en una pronta reanudación del comercio. «No hay que olvidar que Estados Unidos tiene elecciones el próximo año para gobernadores», añadió, sugiriendo posibles motivaciones políticas detrás de la decisión estadounidense. Washington ya había aplicado una medida similar en 2024 por el mismo motivo, y levantó el bloqueo en febrero tras negociaciones entre ambos gobiernos. La nueva restricción se suma a un contexto de crecientes tensiones comerciales. En este mismo escenario, el gobierno de Trump impuso recientemente aranceles a productos del sector automotor, así como al acero y aluminio de distintos países.

title: Trump hablará con el líder chino Xi a final de semana
content: Fuentes estadounidenses dijeron que todavía no se ha fijado una fecha precisa para que las conversaciones se reanuden a nivel de expertos El presidente Donald Trump, afirmó este lunes que la relación ...
resumen:
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, afirmó este lunes que la relación con China es “muy buena”, tras el cierre de un acuerdo para rebajar aranceles mutuos, y aseguró que hablaría con su homólogo chino, Xi Jinping, “quizá a finales de semana”, informó la agencia EFE.

Trump dijo: “No buscamos perjudicar a China. China estaba sufriendo un gran daño. Estaban cerrando fábricas. Había mucha inestabilidad, y estaban muy contentos de poder hacer algo con nosotros. La relación es muy, muy buena. Hablaré con el presidente Xi quizás a finales de semana”.

Tras dos días de negociaciones en Suiza, ambos países cerraron un acuerdo para rebajar en 115 % sus aranceles mutuos por 90 días.

Los gravámenes estadunidenses a los productos chinos quedan a un 30% (de un 145% anterior), frente a un 10% (de 125%) para los estadunidenses.

Trump adelantó que de no alcanzar un pacto comercial más duradero con China en 90 días, no piensa volver a subir los aranceles hasta el 145%, aunque sí afirmó que estos se incrementarían “sustancialmente más”.

Las negociaciones entre China y Estados Unidos se reanudarán próximamente para abordar la resolución en términos prácticos de los desacuerdos comerciales.

El objetivo de Washington es reducir el déficit de $1.2 billones en la balanza comercial estadounidense.

title: It’s Not Just Trump’s Tariff War Hurting BC’s Forest Sector
content: Every Canadian lumber producer that invests south of the border or is considering doing so is also “tariff jumping,” Antweiler said, which means increased profit margins potentially at the expense of ...
resumen:
In August 2022, Canfor Corp. announced plans to spend more than US$200 million to build a new high-tech sawmill in southern Alabama. The Mobile County Industrial Development Authority offered Canfor $14.2 million in combined property and sales tax incentives.

An investigation by The Tyee shows that Canfor, Interfor, and West Fraser have invested nearly US$8.4 billion to buy, expand, or build 59 mills in about a dozen U.S. states over the past 20 years, making the bulk of those investments in Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North and South Carolina and Texas.

The U.S. lumber producers accuse Canadian provinces of subsidizing logging companies through low stumpage fees, which they say resulted in Canada “dumping” softwood lumber into the United States.

Events in B.C., where the bulk of Canada’s lumber exports originate, are equally important. Thanks to decades of logging at rates that the companies and provincial government alike knew could not be sustained, one B.C. mill after another has closed while forestry giants turn their attention to the U.S. South, where the trees grow far faster.

In 1987 and 1988, both were record-setting for the number of trees logged. Those years also marked another first as B.C. adjusted to a new 15 per cent export charge imposed by the U.S. Department of Commerce on imported Canadian lumber.

The favourable difference in the currencies was pivotal in keeping B.C. lumber makers in the game in the lucrative U.S. market. To improve profit margins, they built new supersized mills that upped the amount of lumber produced while lowering the number of workers needed to do the job.

The new threatened doubling of the duties Canadian lumber producers would pay on U.S.-bound lumber shipments — to 34.45 per cent from 14.4 per cent — will likely mean more B.C. mill closures and corresponding increases in Canadian forest company investments south of the border.

The Tyee’s review shows that between them the three companies have, since 2004, spent more than US$8.4 billion in today’s dollars to buy, upgrade and build a combined 59 mills in 13 U.S. states.

From 1988 through the end of 2024, B.C. lumber producers shipped a combined 923 million cubic metres of lumber to buyers outside Canada, including the United States, China and Japan, with the value of those shipments worth a combined $327 billion in today’s dollars. The United States’ share of those exports was 667 million cubic metres of lumber at a combined sales value of $211.6 billion, or $5.71 billion on average per year.

In 2024, B.C.’s lumber shipments to the United States were just shy of 11.3 million cubic metres. In 2005, U.S. buyers bought more than 28.6 million cubic metres of lumber from B.C. lumber makers. In 2021, the total volume of lumber exported from B.C. to the United States stood at 14.3 million cubic metres, half of what it was in 2005.

In each decade from the 1980s on, at the provincial government’s urging, logging companies in B.C. dramatically increased the number of trees they cut down in response to significant insect infestations.

For seven years beginning in 2001, lumber exports to the United States were at their highest and most sustained levels in history. In all, more than 174 million cubic metres of lumber were shipped south in those years.

B.C. frequently set its stumpage rates charged on the trees logged in designated beetle salvage-logging zones at 25 cents per cubic metre.

Canadian lumber producers have paid billions of dollars in duties on their U.S.-bound lumber, duties held by the U.S. Department of Commerce. With the interest accrued on those payments since 2017, the total amount paid approaches US$9 billion.

title: With No Real Policy, Trump Asks Drugmakers to Lower U.S. Prices
content: The president has long complained that the United States pays more for medicines than other wealthy countries. But he offered no clear legal authority to mandate lower prices.
resumen:
On Monday, President Trump signed an executive order asking drugmakers to voluntarily reduce the prices of key medicines in the United States. The order cites no obvious legal authority to mandate lower prices. The order said the administration would consider taking regulatory actions or importing drugs from other countries in the future if drugmakers do not comply.

Last week, Mr. Trump hyped a coming announcement that was “as big as it gets.” On Sunday evening, he teed up the order in a Truth Social post, writing that he would link U.S. drug prices to those in peer countries under a “most favored nation” pricing model. His executive order on Monday does not do that. Pharmaceutical stocks rose Monday on the news.

Mr. Trump’s executive order came just hours after House Republicans offered an expansive set of health care policy changes that would cut around $700 billion from Medicaid and the Obamacare marketplaces over a decade and would cause an estimated 8.6 million Americans to become uninsured. Congress declined to include any provisions to directly limit drug prices in that package.

The executive order also called on federal agencies to investigate why European countries get lower prices and to push them to pay more. The Trump administration has limited leverage to drive up prices in Europe.

Mr. Trump said on Monday before signing the order, “I’m really more knocking the countries than the drug companies.”

With his executive order, Mr. Trump opted not to propose measures that could have had more teeth, such as calling for his administration to work with Congress on legislation or writing regulations to change how government health programs pay for some drugs.

Ameet Sarpatwari, who studies pharmaceutical policy at Harvard Medical School, said, “The executive order reads more like an aspirational statement than a serious attempt to initiate a policy change.”

Mr. Trump has long railed against the current system, in which pharmaceutical companies charge the United States significantly higher prices than the rest of the world.

Mr. Trump threatened to use trade policy to push European countries to pay more for prescription drugs.

In his first term, Mr. Trump tried unsuccessfully to enact a more substantive policy to reduce some drug prices paid by Medicare. That plan would have applied only to 50 drugs, administered at clinics and hospitals. A federal court blocked it.

The White House had teased the announcement as seismic. Monday’s executive order, on its face, calls for much broader changes than Mr. Trump proposed in his first term, affecting more drugs and all Americans, not just some Medicare patients. But it lacks a clear mechanism for enacting the price reductions.

Stacie Dusetzina, a health policy professor at Vanderbilt University who studies drug pricing, said, “It almost sounds like: We’ll just ask for lower prices and see how that goes.” Barring more substantive action, she said, “I would not anticipate drug prices to come down in the near future.”

The order said that if the initial actions did not make enough progress in lowering U.S. drug prices, the Trump administration may “propose a rulemaking plan to impose most-favored-nation pricing.”

Democrats have introduced numerous bills to bring American prices more in line with those of foreign peers, and legislation passed during the Biden administration allows Medicare to negotiate directly on the price of a limited set of drugs used in the program.

The drug industry has also been bracing for punishing tariffs on imported medicines, which Mr. Trump has vowed to impose soon.

Pharmaceutical investors were relieved that Mr. Trump did not propose the more substantive policy he had threatened. After dropping in premarket trading, pharmaceutical stocks rebounded when the details of Mr. Trump’s move became clear. Merck’s stock rose by 6 percent on Monday. Pfizer’s closed up by nearly 4 percent. An index of smaller biotechnology stocks was up 4 percent.

Analysts at the Wall Street bank Jefferies wrote in a note to investors, “Better than feared.” TD Cowen analysts said, “More bark than bite.”

Lobbying groups for drugmakers said the United States should not look to other countries for how much it pays for drugs.

The main industry group, PhRMA, also applauded Mr. Trump for threatening to use trade negotiations to push foreign governments “to pay their fair share for medicines.”

Stephen J. Ubl, PhRMA’s chief executive, said, “U.S. patients should not foot the bill for global innovation.”

Brand-name drug prices in the United States are three times as high, on average, as those in peer nations.

In other wealthy countries, the government generally pays for prescription drugs for the entire population, negotiating substantial discounts from drugmakers. Many other nations do their own comparisons with prices in peer countries to help determine what they are willing to pay.

In the United States, the government has very little formal involvement in setting drug prices, other than the Biden-era program for a limited number of drugs in Medicare. The Trump administration is now overseeing that program.

This month, Senator Josh Hawley, a Republican from Missouri, and Senator Peter Welch, a Democrat from Vermont, introduced a bill that would limit drug prices in the United States to an average of the prices paid by a group of peer countries.

Mr. Welch said he agreed with Mr. Trump that Americans are overpaying and that international comparisons could help set fairer prices. But he thinks Congress needs to tackle the issue to ensure a durable policy.

Mr. Trump’s executive order gave his administration one month to tell drug companies the voluntary “price targets” for certain medicines. A White House official said that weight-loss medicines known as GLP-1s — a class of popular drugs like Zepbound and Wegovy — would likely be among them.

Mr. Trump complained in his news conference Monday that “the fat shot” costs much less in Europe than in the United States.

In most cases, Americans can get these drugs for $500 a month without using insurance. European pharmacies often charge a few hundred dollars less.

title: Tariff Truce With China Demonstrates the Limits of Trump’s Aggression
content: President Trump’s triple-digit tariffs on Chinese products disrupted global trade — but haven’t appeared to result in major concessions from Beijing.
resumen:
President Trump's decision to impose, and then walk back, triple-digit tariffs on Chinese products demonstrated the power and global reach of U.S. trade policy, but also illustrated the limitations of Mr. Trump’s aggressive approach.

The tariffs on Chinese goods, which the United States ratcheted up to a minimum of 145 percent in early April, brought much trade between the countries to a standstill. They caused companies to reroute business globally, importing less from China and more from other countries like Vietnam and Mexico. They forced Chinese factories to shutter, and brought some American importers to the verge of bankruptcy.

Within weeks, Trump officials were saying that the tariffs the president had chosen to impose on one of America’s largest trading partners were unsustainable, and that they were angling to reduce them.

Trade talks between the world’s largest economies in Geneva this weekend concluded with an agreement to reduce stiff levies on each other’s products by more than many analysts had anticipated. Chinese imports will face a minimum tax of 30 percent, down from 145 percent. China will lower its import duty on American goods to 10 percent from 125 percent. The two countries also agreed to hold talks to stabilize the relationship.

The talks this weekend, and the tariff chaos of the past month, did not appear to generate any other immediate concessions from the Chinese other than a commitment to keep talking.

Scott Kennedy, a China expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said the Geneva agreement represents an almost complete U.S. retreat that vindicates Xi’s decision to forcefully retaliate.

Mr. Trump and his advisers contend that the United States holds the strongest cards in trade negotiations.

Through his so-called reciprocal tariffs and maximalist levies on China, the “Art of the Deal” president is employing a strategy that involves manufacturing trade crises in hopes of extracting quick economic concessions. But when confronting an economic power with similar might and perhaps more willingness to endure pain, Mr. Trump opted to stand down, declaring China’s agreement to join him at the negotiating table a win.

Officials essentially said they had determined that they did not want — or intend — to go down the path that the president’s tariffs had set the United States on, of fully decoupling its economy from China.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said at a news conference in Geneva, “We concluded that we have a shared interest. The consensus from both delegations is that neither side wanted a decoupling.”

Mr. Bessent said on the Fox Business Network last month, “They have the most imbalanced economy in the history of the modern world. And I can tell you that this escalation is a loser for them.”

The tariffs proved painful for China, but they were also disruptive for the U.S. economy. American companies had started to warn of coming pain for consumers in the form of higher prices and less availability of products.

U.S. manufacturers were particularly concerned about China’s export restrictions on vital minerals and magnets. And while shipments from China to the United States plunged 21 percent in April from a year earlier, its exports to Southeast Asian countries surged 21 percent.

The decision to temporarily lower tariffs on China provides a welcome reprieve for businesses, but it will also do little to ease longer-run uncertainty that is weighing on U.S. firms. The two governments now have until mid-August to make progress toward a trade deal.

On Monday morning, Mr. Trump said that if the countries did not reach an agreement in that time, tariffs on Chinese products would rise again to be “substantially higher,” though not to 145 percent.

“At 145, you’re really decoupling because nobody’s going to buy,” he added.

Matthew Shay, the chief executive of the National Retail Federation, which represents large and small retailers, called the temporary pause “a critical first step to provide some short-term relief for retailers and other businesses that are in the midst of ordering merchandise for the winter holiday season.”

Gene Seroka, the executive director of the Port of Los Angeles, said on Monday that the 30 percent tariff that remained on China was still substantial, and that the enthusiasm of American consumers and the companies that relied on their shopping habits had been damaged by the threat of tariffs. Ninety days is also a relatively brief time frame for companies to try to restart stopped shipments from China.

Wendy Cutler, the vice president of the Asia Society Policy Institute, said three months was “an extremely short amount of time to address the range of contentious trade matters that remain between the U.S. and China, including dealing with excess manufacturing capacity, excessive subsidization of Chinese firms and transshipment efforts by Chinese companies.”

Mr. Trump has said talks would be focused in part on “opening up” China to American businesses. Officials said they had agreed to set up a regular cadence of talks with China, and suggested that some of those could center on Chinese purchases of U.S. products that would help to balance trade.

Chinese officials also agreed to significant purchases in a 2020 trade deal signed with Mr. Trump that were meant to help balance trade between the countries, but they ultimately did not fulfill them.

In an interview on CNBC on Monday, Mr. Bessent said the 2020 deal could serve as a “starting point” for future talks and blamed the Biden administration for failing to enforce the agreement.

During his confirmation hearing, Mr. Bessent said he intended to push China to honor its commitments to purchase more American farm products.

Michael Pillsbury, who was a top China adviser to Mr. Trump in his first term, said, “Everyone thought in advance that the most important thing is to get Chinese adherence to the 2020 Phase 1 agreement that for many issues provides a foundation for going forward.”

Myron Brilliant, a senior counselor at DGA-Albright Stonebridge Group who advises clients on China, said, “The two governments have given themselves a window to get something done on fentanyl and purchases. But what else will China agree to remains a big question going forward, given our longstanding persistent concerns over their trade policies.”

title: How major global and economic sectors are reacting to U.S. tariff policy
content: Tariffs remain top of mind for many across the economic landscape. The effects have been felt by the building industries in terms of increased costs, disrupted supply chains and economic uncertainty.
resumen:
Tariffs remain top of mind for many across the economic landscape. The effects have been felt by building industries in terms of increased costs, disrupted supply chains and economic uncertainty.

Last week’s webinar, “Trump's Tariffs: Transition or Turmoil?” hosted by Politico and welcoming journalists from across the globe focused on the near-term effects of tariffs, how trade environments have shifted in response, and what the next steps of the Trump Administration might be.

Details of U.S./Canada trade likely to be decided in USMCA renegotiation. Ari Hawkins, a Politico trade reporter, says that the recent meeting between newly-elected Prime Minister Mark Carney and President Donald Trump represents a potential “easing of tension.” While Trump has repeated his “51st state” rhetoric, and Carney stated in the introductory meeting that “Canada is not for sale,” Hawkins still finds the administration’s treatment of Carney to be more favorable when compared with former Prime Minister Trudeau. “For Carney himself, the Trump administration and Trump himself has taken a much calmer tone. It's been more conciliatory that was the goal of this meeting to level set to make sure that they had a path forward for negotiations, and in that sense, both sides did what they needed to do,” he says.

In terms of moving forward on a substantive trade agreement, Nick Taylor-Vaisey, Politico’s Ottawa bureau chief, noted that Trump has underscored that the USCMCA is a “good deal for everybody,” and offered a basic timeline of a review in 2026 or “within the next year.” “So maybe he's open to starting those talks earlier, which a lot of Canadian officials want, but we're waiting for details there,” Taylor-Vaisey says. Hawkins agreed that the administration is likely looking to the USMCA renegotiations to “really get into the weeds of a lot of these tariff disputes" with Canada.

Section 232 tariffs likely to remain and expand. In February, the Trump administration restored 25% tariffs on steel and increased the tariff on aluminum to 25% as well, both actions based on Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962. The administration also removed exemptions from previous tariffs on these materials. Hawkins says that further Section 232 investigations could lead to new tariffs in the coming months on a range of products, including semiconductors, lumber and critical minerals.

While the administration might make exemptions on materials like lumber before those investigations are completed, Hawkins says, they are still likely to face the Section 232 tariffs as part of the administration’s focus on incentivizing manufacturing and development within the U.S. Taylor-Vaisey says that given it’s a time of “flux” for Canada, it’s hard to say what Canada might do with its lumber in terms of new trade agreements.

Unlike the tariffs levied on the basis of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, the Section 232 tariffs are legally tested, says Hawkins, and levied through the Department of Commerce. “It's been legally tested, meaning that it could be more difficult for a judge to overturn that, even though it would still be on the basis of a national emergency,” he says.

title: Calzado mexicano podría sustituir importaciones chinas en EU: Ciceg
content: Los aranceles a la importación de productos chinos en Estados Unidos, por petición del presidente Donald Trump, representan una oportunidad muy prometedora para la recuperación y crecimiento de la ind ...
resumen:
El presidente de la Cámara de la Industria del Calzado del Estado de Guanajuato (Ciceg), Juan Carlos Cashat Usabiaga, reveló que los aranceles a la importación de productos chinos en Estados Unidos, por petición del presidente Donald Trump, representan una oportunidad para la recuperación y crecimiento de la industria del calzado en México, que por calidad y precio puede tomar parte del mercado estadounidense, que representa una demanda anual de 2 mil 700 millones de pares.

La industria del calzado produce 180 millones de pares anuales con una capacidad instalada subutilizada por la alta competencia en el mercado interno con los asiáticos, que podría alcanzar el ciento por ciento en el mediano plazo.

Actualmente se exporta a Estados Unidos 40 millones de pares de zapatos, que representa 84 por ciento de las ventas totales internacionales.

Se podría aumentar gradualmente la producción a 360 millones de pares de zapatos en el mediano plazo.

En 2024 la balanza comercial deficitaria representó importaciones por mil 824 millones de dólares contra ventas por 980 millones de dólares principalmente a Estados Unidos, Guatemala, El Salvador, Panamá, Belice y Países Bajos.

Se pide mantener las cuotas compensatorias a las importaciones de botas, sandalias, tenis y calzado de origen chino impuestas en octubre de 2024 a empresas como Apache Footwear, Bidibi Shoes, Xinlong Footwear y Yaxin Shoes Factory.

A enero de 2025 el volumen físico de producción cayó 7 por ciento a tasa anual sumando 17 meses consecutivos con cifras negativas, causando la pérdida de más de 15 mil empleos y que la capacidad productiva instalada opere solo a 51 por ciento.

En 2024 empresas asiáticas introdujeron al país más de 140 millones de pares de zapatos, sin contar el contrabando y los 30 millones de pares que a través del programa IMMEX ingresaron como mercancía temporal sujeta a transformación sin pagar impuestos.

El presidente de Ciceg pidió que el programa IMMEX sea cancelado para la industria del calzado.

El daño asciende a los 4 mil millones de dólares anuales a través de productos que ingresan por un valor menor a un dólar sin pagar aranceles.

Entre las empresas en México que no han podido competir con los bajos precios y alta presencia de calzado asiático están Andrea, Flexi y Hush Puppies.

title: Trump’s tariffs are now raising prices for car parts. Will your auto insurance increase, too?
content: You may be aware that President Donald Trump’s global tariff war will see Americans paying more for consumer goods, but have you considered the cost of services will also rise?
resumen:
President Donald Trump’s global tariff war will see Americans paying more for consumer goods.

According to a February report from Insurify, the cost of full-coverage car insurance in the U.S. could increase by 8% on average this year with Trump’s 25% import tariffs on car parts made in Mexico and Canada.

The only exemptions are USMCA-compliant parts that qualify for preferential treatment.

Canadian steel and aluminum are facing the same tariff, the price of manufacturing auto parts in America could also skyrocket.

The U.S. imports roughly 32% of its total auto parts from Canada and Mexico, according to data cited in the Insurify report.

Imports of finished cars and trucks from Canada and Mexico also account for one-fifth of all vehicles sold.

USA Today reports that tariffs could make the average cost of a new car rise by about $3,000, according to Wolfe Research.

In February, the American Property Casualty Insurance Association reported that about six in 10 auto replacement parts used in U.S. repair shops are from Canada, Mexico or China.

The national average cost for car repairs is $838, according to a report from the Kelley Blue Book.

Insurify data journalist Matt Brannon projects that New York state will see the biggest increases in insurance rates this year, totalling $489 by end of year.

Nearly a fifth — or $110 of that cost — is directly attributed to tariffs, he reported.

Most insurers have to be approved by state regulators to increase the cost of premiums.

J.P. Morgan Research estimated that the probability of a recession in 2025 was 60%.

title: Dow soars as trade war with China partially paused
content: The Trump administration declared victory in a trade war with China Monday after a temporary economic ceasefire that sent the Dow leaping 1,100 points.
resumen: The Trump administration declared victory in a trade war with China Monday after a temporary economic ceasefire that sent the Dow leaping 1,100 points. According to Secretary of the Treasury Scott Bessent, the “deal” reached between Beijing and Washington will see tariffs temporarily reduced by both governments, leaving U.S. importers paying 30% dues on Chinese made goods while Chinese importers cough up an extra 10% on U.S. goods. The Treasury Secretary said at a press conference in Geneva, Switzerland, “We have reached an agreement on a 90-day pause and substantially moved down the tariff levels — both sides, on the reciprocal tariffs, will move their tariffs down 115%.” The stock markets responded with glee, and by the end of the day the Dow Jones Industrial Average was up about 2.8%, the S&P 500 by about 3%, and the Nasdaq Composite by around 4%. The tariffs had been set at 145% on most Chinese goods entering the U.S. and at 125% on U.S. goods headed into China. The first round of tariffs, ostensibly aimed at reducing the amount of fentanyl and fentanyl precursors illegally brought into the United States but manufactured in China, were established on Feb. 1 and March 3 and each added a 10% tax on U.S. imports from China. The Chinese government swiftly responded by imposing equally sized import duties on U.S. natural gas, coal, farm machinery, food, and some specific agricultural products. Trump’s April 2 “Liberation Day” global tariff announcement added an additional 34% tax on top of the earlier 20%. After China responded on April 4 with broad-based 34% tariffs of their own, Trump announced on April 8 that the U.S. duty would jump by another 50% to 104%. The next day, China answered with an 84% duty on U.S. imports. A day after that Trump upped the U.S. imports tax once more, to 145%, and within days China again responded with their own larger levy, topping out at 125%. Bessent described the sky-high tariffs as a sort of “embargo” and noted that “neither side wants that. We do want trade.” Dropping import fees to 30% and 10%, according to the Chinese Commerce Ministry, “aligns with the expectations of producers and consumers in both countries and serves the interests of both nations as well as the common interests of the world.” The ministry encouraged the Trump Administration to refrain from future use of “the erroneous practice of unilateral tariff hikes.” According to the White House, the 90-day pause on tariffs represents a “historic trade win for the United States” and is a further example of the “art of the deal” in action. According to Harvard economist Dani Rodrik, the agreement doesn’t solve any problems except those that Trump created. Brooke Thomson, the president and CEO of Bay State-based business group the Associated Industries of Massachusetts, said that the plan is a positive development but cautioned a 90-day pause isn’t enough to help restore falling business confidence. According to the Trump Administration’s U.S. Trade Representative, Ambassador Jamieson Greer, the economy will respond well to the negotiated ceasefire. While both Bessent and Greer were in Geneva negotiating on behalf of the U.S. to lower tariffs, Trump was back home defending his tariff policy as an economic winner. According to the U.S. President, the tariffs have meant that “TRILLIONS OF DOLLARS (and therefore, record numbers of JOBS!) HAVE BEEN POURING INTO THE USA. THIS IS BECAUSE OF MY TARIFF POLICY, and our great November 5th Election WIN!”. Monday’s announcement of a reduction in tariffs will apparently not impact import taxes on Chinese steel and aluminum nor will it reinstate the “de minimis” tariff exemption on orders worth less than $800, which the Trump Administration nixed earlier this month. U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer and U.S. Secretary of the Treasury Scott Bessent took part in a press conference after two days of closed-door discussions on trade between the United States and China, in Geneva, Switzerland, Monday, May 12, 2025.

title: ‘We’re Starting to Move Everything’: Trump’s China Deal Frees Up Shipping
content: The temporary lowering of tariffs may compel some U.S. businesses to order goods that they had held off buying after President Trump raised them to 145 percent.
resumen:
Jay Foreman, ejecutivo de una empresa de juguetes, detuvo todos los envíos desde China para evitar pagar el arancel del 145 por ciento del presidente Trump.

El lunes, al enterarse de que Trump estaba reduciendo los aranceles sobre las importaciones chinas durante 90 días, Foreman, director ejecutivo de Basic Fun, con sede en Florida, ordenó a sus proveedores que comenzaran a enviar mercancías de inmediato.

Después de las conversaciones del fin de semana en Ginebra, la administración Trump redujo los aranceles sobre muchas importaciones chinas al 30 por ciento desde el 145 por ciento. China redujo sus aranceles sobre los productos estadounidenses al 10 por ciento desde el 125 por ciento. Si no se llega a un acuerdo en 90 días, los aranceles podrían volver a subir, aunque Trump dijo el lunes que no subirían al 145 por ciento.

Los viajes desde los puertos chinos a la costa oeste de Estados Unidos pueden tardar de dos a tres semanas.

Gene Seroka, director ejecutivo del puerto de Los Ángeles, no espera un gran aumento de las importaciones en las próximas semanas.

El arancel del 30 por ciento sigue siendo alto según los estándares históricos, por lo que los importadores pueden decidir pagarlo solo por los bienes que realmente necesitan.

Foreman de Basic Fun dijo que, si bien el impuesto del 30 por ciento plantearía un desafío para una empresa de tamaño mediano como la suya, era manejable. Dijo que podría discutir la división del costo más alto con sus proveedores y los minoristas que venden sus productos. A este nivel de arancel, los consumidores pueden esperar un aumento de aproximadamente el 15 por ciento en el precio de algunos juguetes, agregó.

En las últimas cinco semanas, las reservas para enviar contenedores desde China a Estados Unidos fueron un 45 por ciento por debajo del nivel del mismo período del año pasado, según datos de Vizion, una empresa de tecnología logística, y Dun & Bradstreet.

El puerto de Los Ángeles recibió un 31 por ciento menos de contenedores la semana pasada que durante la misma semana de 2024, mientras que el número de buques que visitaron el puerto bajó un 20 por ciento, dijo Seroka.

Las tarifas de envío podrían aumentar hasta un 20 por ciento a corto plazo, dijo Peter Sand, analista jefe de Xeneta, una empresa de análisis del mercado de envíos.

title: Trump starts his foreign trip with a crush of problems — and outsized certainty he has the answers
content: The president finds himself navigating a series of geopolitical crises that are casting greater import on the first extended overseas trip of his second term.
resumen:
President Donald Trump began a three-nation visit to the Middle East on Monday. He intended to focus on encouraging Gulf nations to invest billions in the United States. He is now navigating geopolitical crises and searching for hope in global turmoil.

Trump stated that the world is safer than it was a week or six months ago. He expressed confidence about global problems, including tensions in South Asia, sanctions in Syria, and the war in Ukraine.

Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, Qatar Emir Sheikh Tamim al-Thani, and Emirati President Mohammed bin Zayed will assess Trump's plans for resolving the war in Gaza, dealing with Iran's nuclear program, and addressing India-Pakistan tensions.

Trump is demanding that Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy meet in Istanbul this week to discuss ending Russia’s war on Ukraine. Trump projected confidence that the meeting will happen and might visit Turkey if his presence is constructive.

Ukraine’s allies are skeptical about talks and whether Putin wants peace.

The last living American hostage in Gaza, Edan Alexander, was released. Trump framed this as a chance to restart peace negotiations between Israel and Hamas.

Israel Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was more subdued, stating that Israel has not committed to a ceasefire or the release of terrorists.

Trump is considering removing sanctions on the Syrian government.

Trump took credit for preventing India and Pakistan from all-out war. He said he used trade as leverage.

Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi said his country has only "paused" its military action.

Trump's special envoy, Steve Witkoff, held the fourth round of nuclear talks with Iran's foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, in Oman.

The Trump administration has sent mixed messages about Iran's nuclear work.

Trump seemed confident that Iran is engaging rationally and that he will cement a deal soon.

title: Trump's tariff truce with China brings some relief but uncertainty over what's next
content: President Donald Trump's agreement with China to temporarily slash tariffs for 90 days offered the world a bit of welcome relief.
resumen:
President Donald Trump’s agreement with China to temporarily slash tariffs for 90 days offered the world a bit of welcome relief. The Trump administration agreed after talks this weekend in Switzerland to pare back its 145% in tariffs charged on imports from China to 30%. The Chinese government chose to reduce its retaliatory import taxes on U.S. goods from 125% to 10% while the sides continue to negotiate. Trump declared the de-escalation of the trade war a victory, saying he would soon chat with Chinese President Xi Jinping about how to preserve the financial relationship between the world's two largest economies. The tariffs are now elevated from when Trump took office and the scramble to respond to the White House's mix of threats and olive branches might leave CEOs, investors and consumers uneasy and unwilling to take risks.

Most imports will be taxed at a minimum of roughly 10%. The 10% figure has been Trump's baseline. He gave it to most countries for a 90-day negotiating period after his April 2 “Liberation Day” tariff rollout. He kept the 10% rate as part of the framework with the United Kingdom announced last week. Trump's new 30% tariff on Chinese goods includes 20% tied to China's role in fentanyl and the 10% baseline applied elsewhere. Trump said on Friday, “We have many deals coming down the line, but we always have a baseline of 10%.” Sectoral tariffs of 25% on autos, steel and aluminum are still in place, with Trump stressing that pharmaceutical drugs will also soon face import taxes. Trump said Monday that he told House Speaker Mike Johnson and Senate Majority Leader John Thune to include tariff revenues when looking at how to pay for their planned income tax cuts.

Taisu Zhang, a law professor who studies comparative legal and economic history at Yale University, said the chaos from last month probably was not for nothing. Both countries were testing their strengths, with Trump stressing the importance that foreign companies placed on accessing U.S. consumers and China emphasizing its resilience to an external shock. Zhang said, “As recently as February, both sides probably harbored unrealistic assumptions about each other’s economic or political weaknesses or intents. The Americans had an exaggerated sense of their own bargaining power to begin with, and the Chinese may have had an exaggerated sense of their security from American economic pressure.” Zhang said, “The best thing to come out of this agreement, therefore, seems to be a stronger sense of reality on both sides.” In that, Zhang said, it looks like the goals of the two countries align, with China consuming more and the U.S. manufacturing more.

The S&P 500 stock index jumped 3.3% in Monday trading.

If Trump's 145% tariffs caused fewer boats to leave for U.S. ports, the prospect of a slightly lower tariff rate might cause a stampede of shipping containers to flow across the ocean from China. Michael Starr, vice president of growth at the logistics company Zencargo, said, “They can now start shipping for the holiday season. They’re going to rush as many orders out in these 90 days as possible. And yes, the vessels cannot come back as quickly into service as the freight can.”

University of Michigan economist Justin Wolfers stressed that many people would see the 90-day talks as a short-term positive because “moving tariffs from prohibitive and insane to merely very high is good news.”

Kevin Rinz, a senior fellow at the Washington Center for Equitable Growth, said, “Maybe some of those could live with 30%, at least for a while, but in 90 days, what are tariffs with China going to be? Will they go up or down from 30%? If up, how far? I have no idea, and if I were a firm that relies on imports from China, that would cause paralysis.” Rinz, who worked as an economist in the Obama and Biden administrations, tried to model the impact of the labor market based on Trump's own premise that any short-term pain from tariffs would eventually result in long-term gains. His analysis found a drop in hiring. Rinz said, “It turns out, that scenario looks a lot like a recession over the next few years.”

title: US, China Agree To Slash Tariffs In Trade War De-Escalation
content: The United States agreed to lower its tariffs on Chinese goods to 30 per cent while China will reduce its own to 10 per cent. China hailed the “substantial progress” made at the talks, which were held ...
resumen: The United States and China announced Monday an agreement to drastically reduce tit-for-tat tariffs for 90 days. After the first meetings between Washington and Beijing since Trump ratcheted up his trade war, the world’s two biggest economies agreed in a joint statement to bring their triple-digit tariffs down to two figures and continue negotiations. The United States agreed to lower its tariffs on Chinese goods to 30 percent while China will reduce its own to 10 percent. These actions take effect at 12:01 am on Wednesday, according to an executive order released by the White House. Under Trump’s executive order, “de minimis” items sent through the US Postal Service will be hit with duties of 54 percent of their value, or a $100 payment. The prior tariff had been set at 120 percent. US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent described weekend discussions with Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng and international trade representative Li Chenggang as “productive” and “robust” with both sides anticipated to meet again soon. Bessent told CNBC Monday that he expects United States and Chinese representatives to meet again in the coming weeks to work out “a more fulsome agreement.” The US additional tariff rate remains higher than China’s because it includes a 20 percent levy over Trump’s complaints about Chinese exports of chemicals used to make fentanyl, US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer told reporters. In a joint statement, the two sides agreed to “establish a mechanism to continue discussions about economic and trade relations.” China’s commerce ministry said both parties “will conduct rolling consultations on a regular or ad hoc basis in China, the US or agreed third countries.”

title: Trump blinked in trade war with China. Can South-east Asia get a break, too?
content: It took one weekend in Geneva for US President Donald Trump to roll back what has been seen till now as the raison d'etre of his presidency.
resumen: US President Donald Trump rolled back tariffs on goods from China, reducing them from 145% to 30% (10% baseline plus 20% punitive levies). Beijing will slash levies on American products from 125% to 10%. The US decision was seen as a victory for China. The reversal on China raises questions for South-East Asia, where reciprocal tariffs range from 49% on Cambodia to 17% on the Philippines to 10% on Singapore. A rare joint US-China statement announced a dramatic lowering of tariffs. The White House is pushing for less Asean trade with China as the price for better trade terms with the US. The US is vocal about concerns that Chinese goods are being rerouted through Asean countries to bypass US tariffs on China. Vietnam and Malaysia, which face 46% and 24% tariffs respectively, appear especially galvanised. Malaysia is considering strategic purchases from the US, including Boeing aircraft and rare earths. Vietnam has signaled willingness to make significant concessions, including lowering tariffs on American goods and increasing US imports. The Philippines is offering its own tariffs on American goods. An obstacle in negotiations is that the White House is pushing for less Asean trade with China as the price for better trade terms with the US. The US would undoubtedly ask countries to strengthen their transshipment regimes and come down hard on circumvention activities. Asean nations have been keen to offer assurances. Asean nations are ready to take the next step in their FTA with China. They are expected to announce an upgrade to include a digital trade chapter during a meeting at the end of May. Trump has ruled out any extensions to the July 6 deadline to seal trade deals.

title: La gran lección que nos deja la tormenta arancelaria de abril
content: Los aranceles aprobados el pasado mes resultaron ser mayores, más variados y, sobre todo, más disparatados de lo que nadie había previsto, ni siquiera Milei. Las tasas universales del 10% y los ...
resumen:
La guerra arancelaria de Donald Trump ha sacudido las bolsas y solo se vislumbra incertidumbre.

Tras un mes de abril surrealista, intentar prever los movimientos de los mercados con información ampliamente comentada o vender en momentos de pánico carece de sentido.

Los mercados descuentan con rapidez las noticias y opiniones más comentadas.

Las decisiones anunciadas el 2 de abril fueron de tal dimensión que nadie las esperaba, dando paso a una sorpresa negativa.

Los aranceles aprobados y previstos eran de poca importancia.

El presidente Javier Milei elogió los planes de Trump mientras pensaba en lograr un acuerdo comercial con Estados Unidos.

Los aranceles aprobados resultaron ser mayores, más variados y, sobre todo, más disparatados de lo que nadie había previsto, ni siquiera Milei.

Las tasas universales del 10% y los impuestos “recíprocos”, mucho más elevados, agudizaron la incertidumbre.

La renta variable mundial se desplomó y se agravaron las pérdidas del Merval.

Los mercados no pueden anticipar una sorpresa tan absurda y de tal magnitud.

Los supuestos aranceles recíprocos no son recíprocos en absoluto, no tienen nada que ver con los que otros países aplican a Estados Unidos.

El arancel medio de la UE es del 2,7%, y se le ha impuesto un 20%.

El gravamen medio de Vietnam es del 5,1%, y Trump se lo ha subido al 46%.

Los aranceles se calcularon en función del déficit comercial de Estados Unidos con cada país, alegando que los estaban “engañando”.

El tipo universal del 10% también afecta a países con los que EEUU mantiene un superávit comercial, como Argentina.

Las balanzas comerciales nunca predicen, por sí solas, los buenos resultados económicos.

Francia ha registrado déficits comerciales anuales desde 2008, mientras que Alemania, superávits, pero el desempeño económico de Francia fue ligeramente mejor.

Los superávits comerciales no son negativos, ya que las balanzas comerciales no significan ni predicen nada.

Milei está eliminando las barreras al libre comercio.

El 9 de abril Trump suspendió los aranceles “recíprocos” durante 90 días a todos los países menos a China, a la que impuso un castigo adicional.

Las acciones estadounidenses y argentinas subieron más del 9,5% ese día (en USD).

La mayoría de las sesiones a la baja se agrupan alrededor de los días de volatilidad al alza, de modo que es imposible anticiparse a los movimientos del mercado.

Incluso si volvieran a entrar en vigor los aranceles, el efecto sería menor de lo que se teme.

No hay sistemas ni personal suficientes para gestionar su recaudación.

El Departamento de Recaudación del Servicio de Aduanas y Protección de Fronteras de Estados Unidos solo dispone de 2.500 empleados y su tecnología está obsoleta.

Desde el 5 de abril hasta mediados de mes apenas recaudó 500 millones de dólares de los 2000 millones diarios previstos por Trump.

Esta tendencia continuará mientras las empresas puedan eludir una parte de los pagos.

Los aranceles universales exceden el ámbito de la Ley de Emergencia Nacional, invocada por Trump, y ya hay demandas en curso.

Es posible que veamos acuerdos para reducir las barreras comerciales, con el potencial alcista que eso supondría.

Otros países, al margen de China, podrían adoptar represalias, pero no parece probable.

Pregúntese si sabe algo sobre los aranceles de Trump que los demás ignoran.

Salvo que disponga de información desconocida y no haya sido descontada en las cotizaciones, realizar cambios en la cartera en pleno episodio de volatilidad es cuestión de suerte.

En caso de que necesite una rentabilidad a largo plazo similar a la de la renta variable para financiar sus objetivos, salir del mercado es muy arriesgado.

title: Si Colombia se adhiere a la Franja y la Ruta de China, ¿qué sigue? Esto firmaron otros países de América Latina
content: Los escenarios y efectos de lo que el presidente Gustavo Petro pactaría en Pekín. ¿Acuerdo deberá ser revisado?
resumen:
El presidente Gustavo Petro mencionó la posibilidad de firmar la "ruta de la seda" con China, refiriéndose a la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta (BRI).

La BRI, creada en 2013 por el presidente Xi Jinping, es una plataforma de cooperación entre países, con énfasis en el sur global.

América Latina comenzó a vincularse en 2018, con 22 países miembros actualmente, aunque Panamá anunció su retiro. Brasil, México y Paraguay no se han adherido.

La adhesión a la BRI se realiza a través de un memorando de entendimiento.

Los memorandos de entendimiento son figuras no vinculantes del derecho internacional.

El Gobierno Nacional aún no ha revelado el memorando de entendimiento entre Colombia y China.

Los analistas coinciden en que el memorando no tendría que pasar por el Congreso ni la Corte Constitucional.

Después de la firma, la acción bajaría al nivel ministerial para coordinar diálogos con China.

Después de la firma, dependerá de la iniciativa de China y Colombia por generar acercamientos comerciales.

Los memorandos de entendimiento de Argentina, Panamá y Ecuador con China tienen una estructura similar.

Los memorandos enfatizan en la cooperación, el desarrollo económico mutuo, el comercio bilateral, las inversiones y la cooperación tecnológica.

Las tres áreas prioritarias de cooperación son: coordinación de políticas, conectividad de infraestructura, facilitación del comercio e inversiones, integración financiera y el vínculo entre los pueblos.

Los documentos enfatizan en los "principios de mercado" y la participación conjunta de capital público y privado.

La vigencia inicial en los tres documentos es de tres años, renovable automáticamente.

La eventual firma del memorando de entendimiento tendría efectos políticos y económicos.

La adhesión podría ser vista como un gesto geopolítico sensible y una señal de posible realineamiento estratégico.

Una adhesión formal podría afectar la confianza política, la cooperación en seguridad y la percepción de Colombia como socio prioritario de Estados Unidos.

title: América latina teme la caída de las remesas
content: Más allá de la geopolítica que pretende redibujar fronteras, o cambiar de pronto tratados internacionales como el del Canal de Panamá, o subvertir alianzas tradicionales como la de Estados Unidos con ...
resumen:
Las clases populares de América Latina temen la drástica caída de las remesas de los emigrantes.
Una parte importante de la población de América Latina sobrevive gracias al envío de remesas de dinero de sus familiares en el exterior.
La inflación por los cambios económicos por aplicación de nuevos aranceles, retracción económica, o cualquier otra causa, va a limitar la capacidad de ahorro de esos inmigrantes, preferentemente los hispanos en Estados Unidos.
En sus últimas previsiones, el Fondo Monetario Internacional advertía de un posible retroceso del crecimiento de la economía mundial en medio punto, que llegaba hasta un punto de caída en Estados Unidos por el impacto de las decisiones económicas de Donald Trump.
El entonces gerente del Fondo Monetario Internacional, Rodrigo Rato, mostró con detalle en sus estudios el impacto de las remesas en una parte importante de los países del mundo.
Se sabe de la existencia de remesas y de una potente estructura comercial de casas de envíos de dinero; pero no se conoce cuán vital es esa aportación para la vida y la estabilidad de tantos países.
Hay noticia de la suspensión o aplazamiento de viajes turísticos a Estados Unidos -primer destino mundial, al que siguen España y Francia- hasta que lleguen tiempos más seguros.
Las agencias turísticas españolas estiman en unos doce mil los viajeros que han desistido por el momento de esas vacaciones, en los últimos tres meses, optando por destinos menos arriesgados.

title: Al pesimismo siguió la euforia por acuerdo comercial
content: Dos tensos días de negociaciones en un fin de semana en Suiza hubieran sido suficientes en muchos casos para que saliera humo blanco, aunque no suelen serlo ...
resumen: Dos tensos días de negociaciones en un fin de semana en Suiza fueron suficientes para que saliera humo blanco en la disputa comercial entre Estados Unidos y China. Los negociadores estadounidenses y chinos se pusieron de acuerdo para bajar los aranceles recíprocos en un 115% durante 90 días. El presidente Trump había impuesto un arancel del 45% a las importaciones chinas, mientras que Beijing respondió con un gravamen del 25% sobre algunos productos estadounidenses. Los aranceles estadounidenses a las importaciones chinas se reducirán ahora al 30% durante 90 días, mientras que los aranceles chinos a las importaciones estadounidenses disminuirán al 10% durante el mismo período (la pausa comenzará el 14 de mayo). La disputa comercial ya estaba teniendo sus secuelas en las dos economías más grandes del mundo. Los puertos estadounidenses estaban registrando un fuerte descenso en el número de buques procedentes de China, en tanto que la producción de las fábricas en China ya se estaban ralentizando y algunas empresas se habían visto obligadas a despedir a trabajadores. El secretario del Tesoro estadounidense, Scott Bessent, afirmó que el consenso de ambas delegaciones este fin de semana es que ninguna de las partes quiere un desacoplamiento. Bessent expresó que lo que había ocurrido con estos aranceles tan elevados era el equivalente a un embargo, y ninguna de las partes quiere eso. El ministerio de Comercio chino declaró que el acuerdo alcanzado con EE.UU. era un paso importante para resolver las diferencias y sentar las bases para salvar las diferencias y profundizar en la cooperación. El camino de las negociaciones condujo a un punto medio, en beneficio de ambas partes, evitando que ninguna de ellas se acercara al punto de quiebre, y todas las bolsas del mundo, eufóricas, reaccionaron al alza.
